> I never did manage to beat Subian without Sun Bai...

Well, I redid #163 (the other one with Subian) to bring up the 
experience level of the 1st tent and add a 2nd tent near Subian.  Of 
course, there is a cache of invulnerability potions under the tent in 
the lower left hand corer.

I think that illustrates a point.  In the "Slime Lord", if you use 
"F8", "+", and delete keys to control the single slime, the game 
crashes and the slime is level 128.  However, it's no big deal to 
control "Subian" even though Subian's stats are higher in the 1st one.

Redoing the diagonal hedges is a dreaded project.  I might be able to 
rebuild it from stratch faster than manually readjusting things.

My team composed of a fire elemental, barbarian, elf, and 2 clerics 
didn't have that much trouble.

My current team composed of a thief, archer, druid, elf, and 2 clerics 
is having trouble though.

Yes, you understand why I put so much gold and silver in each 
scenario.  Literally, the money is going to build up your team.

I had to cheat with health just to beat "Hedge Free" (#122).  Once I 
took out "Planter", it was no big deal to win, because my clerics 
could just summon skeletons galore. [That bothers me about how easy 
that makes any scenario.  If you can just surive long enough to start 
summoning skeletons, you can win any scenario.]

"Yet Even More Hedges" (#121) [Side note: that maze wasn't copied from 
anything else; strictly created in my head] can't be beat by a single 
character without cheating unless the character is a thief who stays 
cloaked.  Forget using any mages or archmages in that scenario unless 
you keep them permantly invisible.  As long as clerics summon 
skeletons to serve as distractions for the faeries, it's ok.  At one 
point, there were almost 200 opponents in "Yet Even More Hedges" when 
I was walking through (only 58 level 12 druids were put in the 
scenario).  A mob of faeries and a nearby druid can take down any 
character.  Seriously, let this be a lesson: a maze using trees as 
walls with druids that can summon faeries is a very bad idea.  I do 
have one question, though.  If your team went through the maze as a 
whole as opposed to using a single character, would it be an easier?

* * *

BTW, I want to raise the stakes in the Monthly Scenario Contest.  I'd 
like to include the winner's scenario (if I'm the winner, it's 2nd 
place) in the new set of scenarios I'm working on.  I already have a 
scenario in my head "The Chamber of Time" where the God of War can go 
to relive famous battles.  The scenario would be full of exits to 
other scenarios.  That's one of my paths.  My question is where else 
does a God of War go to hang out?  BTW, what kind of character suits a 
god of war?  [Mages/Archmages need not attempt this position.]  [Don't 
worry; he's going to show up in about the same manner as Sun Bai did, 
except having not so innocent backstory.]
